one: ^Nolwazi: Good Afternoon, I am here to deliver these fruit baskets. The older man at the village said you would be able to tell me more about them. I have one similar to it. It belonged to my grandmother.
^Bisola: Are you the police, Did Baba Disun send you? Tayo, can you see now, I told you Baba Disun would not forgive us for not paying him last week. Wicked man!
^Tayo: Madame, please don’t take us, we are sorting out, we will pay him back please.
^Nolwazi: No, my name is Nolwazi, the man only sent me to deliver these. I’m not here to cause trouble; I just need answers.
^Bisola: Ah, Thank God. Madame, please, I would love to help you and thank you, but as you can see, we are dealing with a lot now.
^Nolwazi: Perhaps I can help. What happened?

^Tayo: You see our brother, Emmanuel is sick, so he left us in charge of his market stall, but Bisola and I messed up the orders and prices, now nobody can receive or buy their portions for the day, and we will lose money. Emmanuel will not be happy.
^Bisola: Can you help? We need to figure out the prices of these fruits and vegetables. If you win, we will answer your questions and give you some fruits for free.
three: ^Nolwazi: Okay, I have helped you. Now will you tell me the story behind this fruit basket? It belonged to my grandmother; here is a picture. I do not know who the other woman in the photo is.
^Bisola: It looks very familiar. Tayo, didn’t Emmanuel have a picture like this too?

^Tayo: *Looks at the picture* Yes, that woman, that's nya ila (great-grandmother) and her friend. Baba Disun’s family made those fruit baskets especially for them. From what Emmanuel tells us, she was a great help to our village. You have a lot in common with her.
^Nolwazi: You think we’re similar? Thank you, and thank you for the fruits; hopefully, we see each other again sometime Tayo and Bisola.
^Bisola: We hope to see you again too Nolwazi, we hope you have learned something from us. Have a safe journey!
